title: Zoe Marshall admits having new son put a strain on her marriage to Benji Marshall
text:
She gave birth to son Benjamin Fox in March last year.

And NRL WAG Zoe Marshall has been candid about her journey through motherhood, giving a warts and all account of her highs and lows as a new mum.

Speaking to MamaMia on Tuesday, the 34-year-old admitted she at times felt 'disconnected' from her husband, NRL star Benji Marshall.

'There are still major moments of disconnect': NRL WAG Zoe Marshall (left) admitted on Tuesday that having a newborn son put a strain on her marriage to Benji Marshall (right)

She recounted the pair fighting over how to bathe the baby, with Zoe panicking they'd hurt the child when he got water in his mouth.

Zoe wrote: 'I freaked out, lashed out... And it was Benji's fault. The stakes were so high. I remember feeling so mad at him. Irrationally mad.

'I felt like we couldn't gel. I felt disconnected. Why did everything mean so much now, and why did I always have to blame someone?'

While the pair have learned to work through their feelings, she admitted: 'There are still major moments of disconnect with my husband even though we are great most of the time.'

It comes after the TV presenter told The Daily Telegraph's Confidential that she regrets feeling the pressure as a mother to do it all.

Referring to her post-natal depletion diagnosis, the radio personality said she was 'trying to be a hero'.

While the pair have learned to work through their feelings, she admitted: 'There are still major moments of disconnect with my husband even though we are great most of the time'

'[I was trying] to prove to everyone that I wasn't just a mum, I was still of importance outside of being a mum, I still had my identity. That ended up making me very sick,' Zoe explained.

'I feel like pretty much all women feel that way, even the women who take maternity leave get partway through and feel a massive identity crisis,' she continued.

Zoe went on to say that Instagram trolls criticise her for her parenting choices, as they too, struggle to find a balance between motherhood and career.
